item.title: conductors
item.description: contain free charges Q: Examples of conductors metals solutions of ionic compounds electric charge is distributed “evenly”

item.title: conservation of energy
item.description: energy is conserved within a closed system

item.title: Coulomb’s law
item.description: calculates electric force [!info] Electrostatic force directly prportional to the charges $$F_e\sim{~}Q_1\text{ , }F_e\sim{~}Q_2$$ [!

item.title: electric charge
item.description: [[Coulomb’s law]] Elementary charge $$e=1.6\cdot 10^{-19}C$$ Sign: Q [C] = coulomb [[Work in the electric field]]

item.title: electric field
item.description: for action at a distance [!info] Electric fields charge ←→ field ←→ charge Electric field elektromos térerősség a quantity to characterize electric fields

item.title: Electric state
item.description: Caused by excess or lack of electrons

item.title: Electricity
item.description: [[Electric state]] By rubbing, bodies get into a special state when they attract small nearby objects

item.title: Grounding
item.description: When an object is connected to Earth with a [[conductors|conductor]], it will be at the same [[Work in the electric field#^05d86c|potential]] as it

item.title: insulators
item.description: no free charges Q: Examples of insulators (glass) rubber porcelaine air

item.title: Work in the electric field
item.description: $$W_{\text{by field}}=\vec{F}\cdot \vec{s}=q\cdot \vec{E}\cdot \vec{s}$$ [!info] Voltage $V_{AB}$: potential difference between A and B ($\vec{E}\cdot \vec{s}$) $$W=q\cdot V_{AB}$$ $$V_{AB}=\frac{W}{q}$$ $[V_{AB}]=\frac{J}{C}=1V$ (volt)
